Dear Ms. Phillips:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
10/07/2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.

 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12208 Job descriptions.
(1) An agency shall have a current written job description for
each staff position.
One of 16 new employee records reviewed did not show
documentation of a job description for a person identified as an
Intern.
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
One of eight open foster home records reviewed showed the
foster parent’s first aid re-certification was due 12/1/2020 and
completed late on 6/30/2021.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
(h) A copy of the current children's foster home license
application and children's foster home licensing transaction
record documents from the certifying agency.
(f) & (g):
Two of three borrowed home records reviewed did not show
documentation of (f) and (g) as required by the rule.
(h):
Three of three borrowed home records reviewed did not show
compliance:
4

 One did not show documentation of the foster parent’s
current application and DHS-3706.
 Two other records did not show documentation of the
foster parent’s evaluation and or re-evaluation.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(d) Notify all social service workers who have children placed
in the home that a special evaluation has been initiated.
One of five special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation that all workers who had children placed in the
home were notified.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(2) An agency shall inform foster parents of all of the following
before they are questioned or interviewed regarding a special
evaluation:
(a) That a special evaluation has been initiated.
(b) A clear description of the allegations.
(c) That the foster parents may involve a person of their
choice in any interviews with them involving the special
evaluation if the involvement does not impede the timely
completion of the evaluation.
One of five special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation that (a)-(c) occurred before the foster parent was
questioned and interviewed.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
One of five special evaluations reviewed did not show clear
documentation of the place of contacts for all interviews, nor the
interviewer in those contacts. Additionally, some contact dates
listed in the evaluation as interview dates were not listed in the
methodology section of the report or in MISACWIS.
5

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Three of five special evaluations reviewed did not show

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan

Three of five special evaluations reviewed did not show

home were notified of the corrective action plans and what was
required of the foster parents in the plan.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the
time of the change in placement and the needs that remain to
be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b) as required by the rule.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of 20 updated service plans reviewed were 11, and 12
days late.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2019.

ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care

R400.12212(2)(d) Personnel record

The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
ADM 330 Adoption quarterly progress report.
 The agency was advised using a timeframe of three business day from
the date it receives the child’s adoption placement order and or final
order of adoption in determining when the closing adoption quarterly
report is due, may aid it in this area.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
This incident related to allegations of the foster parents slapping the child with an
open hand across the face and spanking the child on the buttocks. The foster parents
admitted to slapping the child and things getting out of hand. The child had bruises.
The special evaluation found the foster home in noncompliance of the behavior
management rules; and revocation of the foster parents’ license was recommended.
The agency adhered to departmental timeframes and standards related to this
incident.
There were three incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
This first incident related to allegations that the foster mother pushed the child after
the child became angry and balled their fist. The foster mother felt the child was going
to hit her. The special evaluation found the foster parent failed to follow the child’s
behavior management plan and was in noncompliance of the behavior management
rule. A corrective action plan and safety plan was developed with the foster family.
With the exception of R400.1237(6) and R400.12327(7), as cited in this report, the
agency adhered to all other departmental timeframes and standards related to this
incident.
The second incident related to allegations that the foster parents used physical
discipline and hit the foster child with a belt. The foster parents denied hitting the
child, but the foster mother admitted to using a belt to frighten the child. The special
evaluation found the foster parents in noncompliance of the behavior management
rule. A corrective action plan was developed with the foster parents consisting of the
foster parents re-signing the agency’s behavior management policies; and training on
12

parenting tough behaviors, de-escalation techniques in foster care; and behavioral
challenges in foster care.
The agency adhered to departmental timeframes and standards related to this
incident.
The third incident related to allegations that the foster parent restraints the child when
the foster child gets in trouble. The special evaluation evidence substantiated the
allegations and found the foster home in noncompliance of the behavior management
rule. A corrective action plan was developed with the foster around the foster parents
following behavior management techniques set up by the child’s therapist.
With the exception of R400.1237(6) and R400.12327(7), as cited in this report, the
agency adhered to all other departmental timeframes and standards related to this
incident.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
That corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2020 Interim Inspection where it
received the following citations:
 R400.1218(5) for Development of service plans – related to caregivers’ signing
the parent/agency treatment plan agreement.
 Policy FOM 722-6B for Family team meetings.
 Policy FOM 722-8C related to parental signature on parent/agency treatment
plan agreements.
 Policy ADM 300 for Adoptive child assessments.
 Policy ADM 710 for MARE registration.
The agency received repeat violations this inspection related to family team meeting
and caregiver and parental signatures on service plans.
DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
There were no safety alerts indicated this inspection.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
